title.narrative: Project For City Resilience In Afghanistan (Pcr)

description.narrative:
The proposed Programme will build Afghanistan capacity for urban DRR and resilience at three interlinked levels - community, city and national level for safe, resilient and sustainable cities. It will demonstrate how the post-2015 frameworks, namely the Sendai Framework on DRR, Paris Agreement on Climate Change and the SDGs as well as the New Urban Agenda can be localized in a coherent and integrated manner. The experience through the programme will benefit Asia-Pacific as well as other regions, therefore making Afghanistan a global leader in DRR and Sendai Framework implementation.
Overall Objective of the Programme is to assist the National Unity Government to make Afghan cities safe, resilient and sustainable by reducing disaster risk, human and economic losses and impacts, especially on the life of women and girls and vulnerable people.
Specific Objective of the Programme is to strengthen the capacity of selected Afghan cities for disaster risk reduction through a people centred preventive approach and demonstrate innovations in localizing the Sendai Framework and other post-2015 frameworks and agendas.
The Programme targets three cities, Kabul (the capital with medium earthquake risk and some flood risk) and Mazar-i-Sharif (the third largest city with medium earthquake risk and high flood risk). Mazar-i-Sharif is located in North West region which is the most disaster vulnerable region in Afghanistan. The community level activities will target six GAs and 30 CDCs that consist of about 6,000 HH. The direct beneficiaries at community level will be around 54,000 people and 4,250,000 at city level.
Outcome 1: Enhanced urban communities' resilience to disaster and climate change
Output 1.1: Community mobilization for resilience building
The Programme will mobilize approximately 6,000 HH in two cities to formulate CDCs which consist of average 250 households and GAs which consists of about five CDCs. In cooperation and coordination with ANDMA provincial offices and Municipal governments, those CDCs and GAs will be formulated and registered to the municipalities.
Communities will elect its chairperson, vice chairperson, secretary and treasurer through transparent and democratic manner. Gender-mix CDC will be recommended but if not accepted by community, they will formulate Male CDC and Female CDC. In case of establishing Male and Female CDC, the vice chairperson of male CDC will be a female CDC chairperson in order to reflect women's view in the male CDCs which act as general CDC in the community.
Once CDCs are formulated, the chairpersons from each male/female CDC make up the board members of the GAs.
Output 1.2: Community Resilience Action Plan (Community-RAP)
GAs will carry out participatory risk and resilience assessment to identify priorities and infrastructure need. First, with the scientific evidences on disaster risk in the city presented by UN-Habitat team, the community will prepare the risk map which present possible disaster risk areas with information on houses, public buildings and space (e.g. schools, health facility, mosques, parks, public toilets, emergency storage facility, waste collection points), and public infrastructure (e.g. street, bridges, canals, drainage, stairs, street lightning) at risk. Also, vulnerability and capacity assessment will measure the level of community risk awareness, preparedness, current practices and capacity for retrofitting, application of building codes, and safety of infrastructures. Based on the risk map and vulnerability and capacity assessments, the community will formulate Community RAP including disaster preparedness plan. In the process, appropriate technology and financial mechanisms for infrastructure improvement will be identified in coordination with Municipalities, Ministries and academia.
Output 1.3: Community disaster risk awareness and preparedness to multiple hazards strengthened
Based on Community RAP, community will conduct non-structural activities such as disaster drill and disaster education using developed disaster education materials at CDC and GA level, at Mosque, school and community buildings. The Programme also conducts peer learning and exchange visits for sharing good practices.
Output 1.4: Community essential infrastructure more resilient to disaster and climate risk
Based on Community RAP, small scale DRR infrastructures in neighbourhood will be reinforced/build at Gozar level. Example includes; enhanced Flood Canals, improved drainage system, built and rehabilitate mosque, community buildings and public spaces (with public toilets) as escape place in case of earthquake and flash flood. The improvement and construction work will be carried out by community with technical supports by Municipalities and UN-Habitat.
Output 1.5: Reinforced Earthquake resilient houses in two cities
The Programme will support MUDH and ANDMA, in coordination with related stakeholders such as academics and engineering associations to develop the criteria of earthquake vulnerable housing. Based on the criteria, the Programme supports municipalities and ANDMA to identify houses at the risk of seismic failure. In two target cities, the programme will reinforce 50 the most vulnerable houses per city. At the same time, training for masons, housing construction workers, building inspectors and community members will be provided.
To implement this activity, tools developed by UN-Habitat and other organization such as UN-Habitat SHERPA methodologyand the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) Participatory Approach for Safe Shelter Awareness (PASSA)tool will be utilized.
Outcome 2: Strengthened municipal capacity for people-centred preventive DRR
Output 2.1: City Risk and Resilience Profiles
Utilizing existing disaster risk and vulnerability information on targeted cities including the recent survey by ANDMA supported by the World Bank, the Programme will identify multiple hazards and at-risk areas. Municipality and ANDMA provincial office with support from academics will develop risk/hazard mapping integrating with geospatial information from “State of Afghan Cities” data which has land use data with dwelling information considering social environmental and economic factors that contribute to vulnerability.
The Programme will also support capacity assessment of Municipalities' capacity that includes staff, institution and infrastructure, using proven tools including the Sendai Framework Urban-Local Indicators. Together with those baseline data, structural and non-structural needs will be identified.
Output 2.2: People-centred and Risk-informed City Resilience Action Plans (City RAP)
The Municipality in collaboration with ANDMA will formulate City Resilience Action Plan (City RAP) in participatory way. City RAP will be developed based on City Risk and Resilience Profile (Output 2.1) and ensures that City RAP embrace Community-RAP and their implementation (Outcome 1).
The capacity of Municipality government and ANDMA provincial office will be enhanced through developing partnerships with communities, academia, engineer associations, civil society organization (CSO) and private sector through this participatory process. In the implementation stage, cooperation of all these stakeholders are essential.
Output 2.3: Structural/Non-Structural improvements for more resilient Cities
Based on City RAP (Output 2.2), concrete priority structural and non-structural measures will be implemented to strengthen the resilience of the city such as;
• Improve/develop critical infrastructure such as canal/river bank improvement, drainage system, vulnerable bridges and shelters; Plant vegetation on slopes, reinforce public buildings such as schools, health facilities and government buildings;
• Advocate/raise awareness on disaster risk by distributing DRR information, organizing events, public service announcements (PSA) through radio;
• Strengthen institutional capacity for risk-informed planning and decision making by Municipality government and ANDMA provincial office through on-the job-training and workshops;
• Identify gaps and reinforce the implementation of Building Code, training for construction workers/private sector on DRR and strengthening capacity of municipal government on Public-Private Partnership (e.g. for seismic resilient design housing)
Output 2.4: Successful Afghan community and city resilience building approaches institutionalized and replicated
In order to spread the impact of the Programme Municipality governments and ANDMA provincial offices will disseminate good practices/lessons learnt through workshops and knowledge products.
The Programme will also share successful Community-RAP and City-RAP for scaling up in other cities. Municipality and ANDMA provincial officials will be trained on these approaches and provided with tools to facilitate other communities in applying good practices. In addition, international training will be provided for the targeted cities to learn best practices from Japan and other countries in the region.
Outcome 3: Strengthened national capacity for risk-sensitive urban development to contribute to Sendai Framework implementation/ monitoring
Output 3.1: Improved risk-sensitive urban policy and decision support tools
National level workshops will be held to share good practices and lessons learned on building resilience at community and municipal levels so that those good practices will be reflected in national policy, procedures and tools to support decision making.
The Programme will also provide policy recommendations and technical support for the improvement of policies and regulations for risk-sensitive and resilient urban infrastructure planning and development, especially for MUDH on Resilient Urban Policy and for DMM/IDLG and MRRD on Citizen Charter Afghanistan Project.
Output 3.2: Demonstration of coherent implementation and monitoring of Sendai Framework, SDGs and New Urban Agenda
The Programme will support the roll out of Sendai Framework monitor at national level in Afghanistan with participation of all relevant stakeholders. This will take into consideration the related SDGs and their targets and indicators those to monitor the Paris Agreement and New Urban Agenda. It will also support ANDMA to establish linkage with the City Risk and Resilience Profiles (Output 2.1) as local monitoring of Sendai Framework.
In addition, the Programme will promote city-to-city learning to share successful approaches through experience sharing workshops and seminars among Afghan cities. It will also promote Afghan experience sharing at regional and global level through regional and global platforms for DRR.
Output 3.3: People-centred preventive approach to disaster promoted in Afghanistan through practical actions by the government
The Programme will support risk sensitive planning in National Citizen Charter Afghanistan Project through providing advices, draft guidelines and awareness rising materials for DRR mainstreaming in “Citizen Charter” (both in rural and urban).
